chunks.text:
MINISTRY OF EDUCATION AND TRAINING NATIONAL ECONOMICS UNIVERSITY | SOCIALIST REPUBLIC OF VIETNAM Independence – Freedom – Happiness
COURSE SYLLABUS (Issued attached Decision of NEU’s President,           ,            , 2023) | COURSE SYLLABUS (Issued attached Decision of NEU’s President,           ,            , 2023)
Bachelor of Software Engineering (SE) | Bachelor of Software Engineering (SE)

* Title: Net Programming
* Code: CNTT1130
* Credits: 3 (45 hours)
* Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
+ Lecture: 30 hrs
+ Exercises on class: 20 hrs
+ Presentation and Discussion: 20 hrs
+ Self-study: 50 hrs
* Parallel course(s):
* Prerequisite course(s): CNTT1128, CNTT1131
* Department conducting the course:
+ Faculty: Information Technology; Room 1310, Building A1, National Economics University; Phone number: 024.36280.280 (6334)
- MSc. Tống Thị Minh Ngọc, Tel: 0913002241, Email: ngoctm@neu.edu.vn
- MSc. Phạm Thảo ,                Tel: 0966986689.	 Email: thaop@neu.edu.vn
* Kind of the course:

Foundation □ | Foundation □ | Fundamental (x) | Fundamental (x)
Compulsory □ | Elective □ | Compulsory □ | Elective (x)
* Course language: 	In English
* Meeting hour:

The module helps students understand and fluently use the .Net Programming language. Know programming techniques with ADO.Net. Students practice submission exercises on the Window Form platform and work with databases, applying problems in Economic and Technical management. Students know how to use the basic structures of programming languages, work with databases and reports. Ability to program management problems in economics and learn technology as well as any programming language that interacts with databases.
The module also aims to train thinking skills and the ability to self-learn knowledge about .Net Programming methods by working independently as well as in groups. Learners have the skills to build a practical, applicable application with an appropriate database.

(1) Hương Lan (2005) Kỹ thuật lập trình ứng dụng C#.Net, NXB Lao Động Xã Hội.
(2) Phạm Hữu Khang, Phương Lan, Hoàng Đức Hải (2005). Kỹ thuật lập trình ứng dụng Visual Basic.Net, Nhà xuất bản Lao động – Xã hội

(1) Phạm Đức Lập, Hướng dẫn lập trình Visual Basic.Net (file điện tử)
(2). David McAmis (2004) Professional Crystal Reports® for Visual Studio®.NET

Table 4. Course goals
Goals | Goals Description | PLOs | Proficiency scale
G1 | The module provides learners with knowledge on how to approach Dot Net programming and application programming on Windows. Develop application programs in management and economic problems. | PLO 1 | 2
G2 | Studying programming skills and thinking, practical analysis skills, and database design. Build basic functions to update information, search, and report statistical data of the problem according to business requirements. | PLO 2 | 3
G3 | The course contributes to developing the ability to work independently and in groups, understanding work responsibilities and professional ethics. | PLO 3 | 3

Table 5. Course learning outcomes (CLOs)
Goals | CLOs | CLOs Description | Teaching level (I,T,U)
G1 | CLO1.1 | Understand Dot Net programming method, learn structures, keywords, operators. Distinguish the characteristics of controls in programming. | I
G1 | CLO1.2 | Apply extended controls related to database types. | T
G1 | CLO1.3 | Apply Dot Net programming thinking to apply specific problems. | T
G2 | CLO2.1 | Have skills in analyzing, designing and building functions applicable to each specific type of article. | T
G2 | CLO2.2 | Have programming skills and thinking to solve application problems with a database management system that meets the requirements. | T
G3 | CLO3.1 | Able to self-study and research materials to complete assigned lessons and exercises. | U
G3 | CLO3.2 | Have a sense of classroom discipline, comply with classroom rules, have a spirit of cooperation and personal responsibility for activities assigned by the instructor. | U
G3 | CLO3.3 | Ability to self-study, understand documents on your own or combine into study groups. | U

Table 6. Assessment summary
Assessments | CLOs | Weighting (%) | Week
Formative assessment | Formative assessment | Formative assessment | Formative assessment
Participant: Learning attitude Answers questions Discussions | CLO1.x CLO2.x CLO3.x | 10% | -
Midterm assessment | Midterm assessment | Midterm assessment | Midterm assessment
Individual test 1: Quiz (20 Questions) Practical Exercise (3 Exercises) | CLO1.x CLO2.x CLO3.x | 40% | 8
Individual test 2: Quiz (10 Questions) Practical Exercise (3 Exercises) Group works | CLO1.x CLO2.x CLO3.x | 40% | 14
Summative assessment | Summative assessment | Summative assessment | Summative assessment
Final exam | CLO1.x CLO2.x CLO3.x | 50% | As scheduled
* Rubrics:
Rubric 1: Participant

Areas of assessment | Weighting (%) | Excellence | Good | Fair | Poor
Participant | 10 | 8.5 – 10 points | 6.5 – 8.4 points | 4.0 – 6.4 points | 0 – 3.9 points
Rubric 2: Individual tests
Areas of assessment | Weighting (%) | Excellence | Good | Fair | Poor
Individual tests | 20 | 8.5 – 10 points | 6.5 – 8.4 points | 4.0 – 6.4 points | 0 – 3.9 points
Rubric 3: Group works

Areas of assessment | Weighting (%) | Excellence | Good | Fair | Poor
Group works | 20 | 8.5 – 10 points | 6.5 – 8.4 points | 4.0 – 6.4 points | 0 – 3.9 points
Rubric 4: Final exam
Areas of assessment | Weighting (%) | Excellence | Good | Fair | Poor
Final exam | 50 | 8.5 – 10 points | 6.5 – 8.4 points | 4.0 – 6.4 points | 0 – 3.9 points

Table 7. Course outline
Week | Content | Readings requirement | CLOs | Teaching-learning activities | Assessment
[1] | [2] | [3] | [4] | [5] | [6]
1-2 | Chapter 1. Introduction 1.1 Introduction to the Visual Basic.Net environment 1.2 Components (internal controls) in Visual Basic.Net 1.3 Working with Project | Read textbook: Chapter 1,2 from [1] and additional references | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO1.3 | Pre-Reading text Homework Lecturing Individual testing Computer Lab | Rubric 1 Rubric 2
3-6 | Chapter 2. Working with Programming Language Visual Basic.Net 2.1 Working with Class 2.2 Working with procedures 2.3 Error handling. 2.4 File processing. | Read textbook: Chapter 2,3,4, from [2] and additional references | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO1.3 | Pre-Reading text Homework Lecturing Group discussion Individual testing Programming on the computers | Rubric 1 Rubric 2
7-11 | Chapter 3. Working with Conversation box and advanced controls 3.1 Menu constructions 3.2 Dialog Box 3.3 Additional, advanced controls | Read textbook: Chapter 7,8, 9, | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO1.3 | Pre-Reading text Homework Lecturing Group discussion Individual testing Programming on the computers | Rubric 1 Rubric 2
12-13 | Chapter4: Working connect to the database 4.1 Objects working with databases 4.2 Connect to the database management system 4.3 Working with Reports | Read textbook: Chapter 9, 12, 14, from [1] and additional references | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO1.3 | Pre-Reading text Homework Lecturing Group discussion Individual testing Computer Lab | Rubric 1 Rubric 2
14 | Group works | Read textbook: Chapter 1-14, from [1] and additional references | CLO1.1 CLO1.1 CLO1.3 CLO2.1 CLO2.2 CLO3.1 CLO3.2 CLO3.3 | Group works Programming on the computers | Rubric 3
15 | Course review | Read textbook: Chapter 1,2,3,4, from [1], Chapter 2,3,4, 9, 10, 12 from [2], and additional references | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO1.3 CLO2.1 CLO2.2 | Pre-Reading text Lecturing Group discussion Programming on the computers | Rubric 1
- | Final exam | - | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO1.3 CLO2.1 CLO2.2 CLO3.1 CLO3.2 CLO3.3 | Students take exams according to given schedule Programming on the computers | Rubric 4
- Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).

chunks.text:
- Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
- Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
- Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
chunks.breadcrumbs: 8. COURSE REQUIREMENT & EXPECTATION > 8.2. Requirements for attending classes

chunks.text:
- The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
- Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
- Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.

Faculty Dean | NEU’s President
PhD Pham Xuan Lam | Prof. PhD Pham Hong Chuong

Bachelor of Software Engineering (SE) | Bachelor of Software Engineering (SE)
1. COURSE INFORMATION
* Title: Net Programming
* Code: CNTT1130
* Credits: 3 (45 hours)
* Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
+ Lecture: 30 hrs
+ Exercises on class: 20 hrs
+ Presentation and Discussion: 20 hrs
+ Self-study: 50 hrs
* Parallel course(s):
* Prerequisite course(s): CNTT1128, CNTT1131
* Department conducting the course:
+ Faculty: Information Technology; Room 1310, Building A1, National Economics University; Phone number: 024.36280.280 (6334)

* Kind of the course:
Foundation □ | Foundation □ | Fundamental (x) | Fundamental (x)
Compulsory □ | Elective □ | Compulsory □ | Elective (x)
* Course language: 	In English

2. COURSE DESCRIPTIONS
The module helps students understand and fluently use the .Net Programming language. Know programming techniques with ADO.Net. Students practice submission exercises on the Window Form platform and work with databases, applying problems in Economic and Technical management. Students know how to use the basic structures of programming languages, work with databases and reports. Ability to program management problems in economics and learn technology as well as any programming language that interacts with databases.
The module also aims to train thinking skills and the ability to self-learn knowledge about .Net Programming methods by working independently as well as in groups. Learners have the skills to build a practical, applicable application with an appropriate database.
3. LEARNING RESOURCES
Required textbooks:
(1) Hương Lan (2005) Kỹ thuật lập trình ứng dụng C#.Net, NXB Lao Động Xã Hội.
(2) Phạm Hữu Khang, Phương Lan, Hoàng Đức Hải (2005). Kỹ thuật lập trình ứng dụng Visual Basic.Net, Nhà xuất bản Lao động – Xã hội
Other references
(1) Phạm Đức Lập, Hướng dẫn lập trình Visual Basic.Net (file điện tử)
(2). David McAmis (2004) Professional Crystal Reports® for Visual Studio®.NET

Table 4. Course goals

G1 | The module provides learners with knowledge on how to approach Dot Net programming and application programming on Windows. Develop application programs in management and economic problems. | PLO 1 | 2
G2 | Studying programming skills and thinking, practical analysis skills, and database design. Build basic functions to update information, search, and report statistical data of the problem according to business requirements. | PLO 2 | 3
G3 | The course contributes to developing the ability to work independently and in groups, understanding work responsibilities and professional ethics. | PLO 3 | 3

Goals | CLOs | CLOs Description | Teaching level (I,T,U)

G1 | CLO1.2 | Apply extended controls related to database types. | T
G1 | CLO1.3 | Apply Dot Net programming thinking to apply specific problems. | T
G2 | CLO2.1 | Have skills in analyzing, designing and building functions applicable to each specific type of article. | T
G2 | CLO2.2 | Have programming skills and thinking to solve application problems with a database management system that meets the requirements. | T
G3 | CLO3.1 | Able to self-study and research materials to complete assigned lessons and exercises. | U
G3 | CLO3.2 | Have a sense of classroom discipline, comply with classroom rules, have a spirit of cooperation and personal responsibility for activities assigned by the instructor. | U
G3 | CLO3.3 | Ability to self-study, understand documents on your own or combine into study groups. | U

3-6 | Chapter 2. Working with Programming Language Visual Basic.Net 2.1 Working with Class 2.2 Working with procedures 2.3 Error handling. 2.4 File processing. | Read textbook: Chapter 2,3,4, from [2] and additional references | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO1.3 | Pre-Reading text Homework Lecturing Group discussion Individual testing Programming on the computers | Rubric 1 Rubric 2
7-11 | Chapter 3. Working with Conversation box and advanced controls 3.1 Menu constructions 3.2 Dialog Box 3.3 Additional, advanced controls | Read textbook: Chapter 7,8, 9, | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO1.3 | Pre-Reading text Homework Lecturing Group discussion Individual testing Programming on the computers | Rubric 1 Rubric 2

14 | Group works | Read textbook: Chapter 1-14, from [1] and additional references | CLO1.1 CLO1.1 CLO1.3 CLO2.1 CLO2.2 CLO3.1 CLO3.2 CLO3.3 | Group works Programming on the computers | Rubric 3
15 | Course review | Read textbook: Chapter 1,2,3,4, from [1], Chapter 2,3,4, 9, 10, 12 from [2], and additional references | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO1.3 CLO2.1 CLO2.2 | Pre-Reading text Lecturing Group discussion Programming on the computers | Rubric 1
- | Final exam | - | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO1.3 CLO2.1 CLO2.2 CLO3.1 CLO3.2 CLO3.3 | Students take exams according to given schedule Programming on the computers | Rubric 4
8. COURSE REQUIREMENT & EXPECTATION
8.1. Requirements for taking final /terminal exams
- Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).
8.2. Requirements for attending classes
- Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
- Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
- Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
8.3. Requirements for in-class behaviour
- The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
- Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
- Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.
Faculty Dean | NEU’s President
PhD Pham Xuan Lam | Prof. PhD Pham Hong Chuong
